block.p: Family Revelry, With Reptiles WEDNESDAY -- The American Museum of Natural History will hold its annual family party, with activities for children and adults, including arts and crafts, songs, storytelling and encounters with live reptiles. The event, which begins with a reception at 5:30 p.m., raises money for the museum's educational and public programs. Tickets, $100; $50 for children, from (212) 769-5166.

Family Revelry, With Reptiles WEDNESDAY -- The American Museum of Natural History will hold its annual family party, with activities for children and adults, including arts and crafts, songs, storytelling and encounters with live reptiles. The event, which begins with a reception at 5:30 p.m., raises money for the museum's educational and public programs. Tickets, $100; $50 for children, from (212) 769-5166.

Halloween Ball WEDNESDAY -- The Central Park Conservancy's annual Halloween ball will be held in a tent on the Mall in Central Park. The event will raise money for the organization's park maintenance and restoration activities. Drinks will be served at 7, followed by dinner and dancing to the music of the Hank Lane Orchestra at 8. Tickets, $500, from (212) 310-6616.

Rerunning the Olympics WEDNESDAY -- Film from the Sydney Olympics and demonstrations by Olympic athletes will be highlights at the annual dinner of the New York chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. The black-tie evening, at the New York Hilton, will raise money for local programs and research supported by the society. A cocktail reception at 6 p.m. will be followed by dinner at 7:15. Tickets, $500, from (212) 463-7787, ext. 3016.

Diplomatic Dining THURSDAY -- The annual Ambassadors Dinner, at the New York Sheraton, will raise money for the United Nations Association, which supports educational, advocacy and policy study programs. James D. Wolfensohn, the president of the World Bank, will be honored, and Robert E. Rubin, Barbara Walters and Kofi Annan are among those scheduled to speak. Black tie or national dress. Drinks at 7 will be followed by dinner at 8. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 907-1356.

Company for the Clown THURSDAY -- A masquerade ball at the Ronald McDonald House, 405 East 73rd Street (First Avenue), will raise money for the organization's educational, cultural and recreational programs for ailing children and their families. A silent auction of gift certificates, handbags, jewelry, clothing and other items will begin at 6:30 p.m. Drinks and hors d'oeuvres will be served, and Rhythm Nation will provide the music. The organizers suggest guests wear costumes or business attire. Tickets, $50, from (212) 639-0100, or $60 at the door.

Hemophilia Foundation THURSDAY -- An evening of amusement-park diversions and casino games will raise money for the National Hemophilia Foundation's programs and support research for a cure. The event, at Dezerland, 270 11th Avenue (28th Street), will give guests a chance to try their hand with batting cages, bumper cars, miniature golf and other activities. The evening begins at 6 with cocktails and a buffet dinner. Tickets, $100, from (212) 328-3722.

A Hand for Show People FRIDAY -- A Halloween ball at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts, 172 Norfolk Street (Houston Street) will raise money for the Actors' Fund of America. The organization helps needy entertainers. Cocktails at 6:30 will be followed by a buffet dinner, dancing and a raffle of Broadway tickets, vacation trips and other items. Tickets, $75, from (212) 221-7300, ext. 134, or $85 at the door.

Fine Arts on the Hudson FRIDAY -- An auction of fine art will raise money for the exhibitions and public education programs of the Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Avenue, in Yonkers. The evening begins with cocktails and a buffet at 6. A live auction of paintings, photographs and other artworks will be held at 8. Tickets and information, $50, from (914) 963-4550, ext. 213.

A New Chamber Season FRIDAY -- The soprano Lauren Flanigan, the pianist Yefim Bronfman and the violinist Elmar Oliveira will perform in celebration of the New York Chamber Symphony's 24th season. The event, to be held at the W New York Hotel, 541 Lexington Avenue (49th Street), will raise money for the organization's performance and public education programs. A Champagne reception begins at 7, with the performances and a dinner prepared by a group of New York chefs at 8. Tickets, $500, from (212) 262-6927, ext. 10.

Costumes in the Round SATURDAY -- A costume ball at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum will raise money for the museum's exhibitions, scholarly publications and educational programs. The evening begins at 10. Cocktails, hors d'oeuvres and desserts will be served. Black tie or costume. Tickets, $135, from (212) 423-3534, or $150 at the door.

Fulbright Honors OCT. 30 -- A dinner and evening of musical performances at the University Club will raise money for the national programs of the Fulbright Association. A quartet of students from the Juilliard School will perform during a cocktail reception at 7. At 8, Karen Parks, a soprano and a 1995 Fulbright fellow, will sing with the United Nations International School Concert Choir. After dinner, the violinist Midori will introduce a trio of clarinet, cello and piano, which will perform Beethoven's Opus 11 in B flat. Schuyler G. Chapin will be the master of ceremonies for the evening, which will include the presentation of lifetime achievement awards to three former Fulbright fellows. They are Arlene Alda, a photographer, musician and children's book author; Barbara Knowles Debs, a former president of Manhattanville College; and her husband, Richard A. Debs, an emeritus chairman of Carnegie Hall. Black tie or national dress is suggested. Tickets, $1,000, from (202) 467-6500.

Green Eggs and Ham? OCT. 30 -- Guests at a fund-raiser for High 5 Tickets to the Arts will attend a preview performance of ''Seussical the Musical'' at the Richard Rodgers Theater. The event will raise money for High 5, an organization that works with New York cultural institutions to arrange reduced-cost tickets for New York City teenagers wishing to attend cultural events and other arts programs. The evening begins with cocktails and a buffet at 6 at Babalu, 327 West 44th Street (Eighth Avenue). The performance begins at 8. Tickets, $250, from (212) 750-0555, ext. 204.

Friends of the Israel Museum OCT. 30 -- A black-tie gala at the Waldorf-Astoria will raise money for the Israel Museum in Jerusalem and for new exhibitions and educational programs in the museum's youth wing. The evening begins with a cocktail reception at 7, followed by dinner at 8. The soprano Arianna Zukerman will perform. Tickets, $1,250, from (212) 997-5611.

Building a Hospital OCT. 30 -- Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx will benefit from the New York premiere of ''Blue Moon,'' a film featuring Rita Moreno and Ben Gazzara. The screening, which begins at 7 at Cinema 1, 1001 Third Avenue (at 60th Street) in Manhattan, will raise money to help complete Montefiore's new Children's Hospital. Drinks and hors d'oeuvres will immediately follow at Acacia, 217 East 59th Street (Third Avenue). Tickets, $250, or $100 for the screening alone, from (718) 920-2959.

Police Athletic League Party OCT. 31 -- A costume party and trick-or-treating amid the toys of F. A. O. Schwarz, 767 Fifth Avenue (59th Street), will raise money for the recreational, educational, cultural and social programs of the Police Athletic League. The evening, which includes magic acts, storytelling, music, dancing and a 30-second ''grab all you can'' contest, begins at 7. Tickets, $60 for children and $120 for adults, from (212) 477-9450, ext. 303.
